channel.title: Whats with the M in your run
channel.description:
In the run batch there's how much RAM u want to use to run your server [code] 1024M [/code]
Now my question is what does it actually do, yeah of course how much ram u use to run the server but i mean does putting it higher or lower changes your server performance?
and if yes why shouldn't you put it on like 100GB as example

item.title: Whats with the M in your run
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

Davidi2:

It’s how much memory your server can use. Basically if your server uses more memory than is allocated there, you will get an OutOfMemory exception.

This, basically it limits the memory being used on the server, if you are using a vps or something I would put it to 80% of your VPS’s memory so you can still work on it while it runs.

Read full topic
item.source: Whats with the M in your run

item.title: Whats with the M in your run
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

And I once had the problem on my old computer
something with can’t run JVM machine or something,

the xmx was set on 1024
when I lowered the xmx512 the error was gone,

so if u in theory can set it high, what was that error

Read full topic
item.source: Whats with the M in your run

item.title: Whats with the M in your run
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

It depends on whether it is Xmx or Xms. Xmx is the maximal amount the application can use, whereas Xms is the minimal. And adding to what David said about good practice, it’s better practice to understand why the system uses too much memory before just bumping up the amount the application can use. Ideally, these servers have way too little features to require more than 256mb of memory. They use as much as they do because they are poorly engineered and developed.

Read full topic
item.source: Whats with the M in your run

item.title: Whats with the M in your run
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

It’s good practice to put it as low as you know wont crash your program. If it’s a dedicated server, you can allocate as much memory as you have, but otherwise just allocate as much as you don’t need.

Read full topic
